Title.evidence: Ultrasound-guided percutaneous cryoneurolysis improves maximum inspired lung volume while concurrently decreasing pain and opioid consumption after traumatic rib fracture.

Trial_Design.evidence: Adults with one to six traumatic rib fractures were randomized to either active cryoneurolysis and sham peripheral nerve block or sham cryoneurolysis and active peripheral nerve block in a participant/observer-masked fashion.

Participants.evidence: Adults with one to six traumatic rib fractures were randomized.

Intervention.evidence: randomized to either active cryoneurolysis and sham peripheral nerve block or sham cryoneurolysis and active peripheral nerve block

Objective.evidence: The authors hypothesized that cryoneurolysis would improve analgesia and inspired volume after rib fracture.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary endpoint was the maximum inspired volume the day after the procedure as measured with an incentive spirometer.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Adults with one to six traumatic rib fractures were randomized.

Number_Randomised.evidence: n = 11 for cryoneurolysis and n = 9 for peripheral nerve block

Number_Analysed.evidence: n = 11 for cryoneurolysis and n = 9 for peripheral nerve block

Result_Outcome.evidence: mean difference, 496; 95% CI, –428 to 1,420; t test P = 0.269
